thread.title: Sam Gagner, Claude Giroux 'sick' goals lift Flyers to rare shootout win - NJ.com
thread.title_full: Sam Gagner, Claude Giroux 'sick' goals lift Flyers to rare shootout win - NJ.com

title: Sam Gagner, Claude Giroux 'sick' goals lift Flyers to rare shootout win - NJ.com
text:
Comments 
PHILADELPHIA — Flyers forward Sam Gagner was in the Western Conference playing for the Edmonton Oilers for his first seven NHL seasons and then with the Arizona Coyotes last season, so he had no idea how bad his new team has been in shootouts. 
He didn't know the Flyers had won fewer than a third of their shootouts since they were put into the game in 2005-06. 
"I just heard last year they had a tough time," Gagner said Saturday night in the middle of a Flyers dressing room that included a lot of happy players. 
They'd just won their first shootout of the season, pulling out a 3-2 victory at Wells Fargo Center. 
Most of the same players lived a lot of past shootout misery. They lost 11 of 14 last season, leaving them 30-62 all-time. 
None of that mattered on this late October night when the Flyers beat Rangers superstar goalie Henrik Lundqvist on one of his best nights. 
ALSO: Flyers terrified when realizing Raffl wasn't faking bench collapse 
Lundqvist made 46 saves to get the Rangers into the shootout, but was beaten in the skills competition on the first two shots coming his way, roofed backhanders by Gagner and Claude Giroux off moves Flyers defenseman Mark Streit called "sick." 
Up 2-0 quickly in the shootout, Flyers goalie Steve Mason made the lead stand. Derek Stepan, the Rangers' second shooter, scored to keep his team alive, but after Lundqvist denied Wayne Simmonds to start the third round, Mason made a left pad save on Dominic Moore to win it for the Flyers. 
"When (Giroux) goes out there and gives you a two-goal lead in that situation, that's a must win for the goaltender," Mason said. 
Mason's been a very solid No. 1 goalie since joining the Flyers in an April 2013 trade, but he fit right in with everyone else regularly stinking it up in shootouts. 
Giroux's shootout goal was a long time coming. His hands are as good as anyone's in the league, yet he was just 1-for-12 in shootouts last season after being good in them earlier in his career. 
Gagner, who scored 20 shootout goals in 62 shots in past seasons, gives the Flyers another very skilled shooter. 
"I played with Sammy in juniors and he had this patented move that was almost a guaranteed goal every time," Mason said. "So to see him go down there with some pretty slick hands ..." 
Gagner didn't use his "patented move" to beat Lundqvist. 
"I normally go forehand," he said. 
Gagner tried it on his 3-on-3 overtime breakaway, but the puck slipped off his stick as he was moving it to his forehand side and he never got a shot off. 
Picked by coach Dave Hakstol to start the shootout — the Flyers opted to shoot first — Gagner decided to "switch it up." and his backhander beat Lundqvist. 
"The shootout's a different animal," Gagner said. "Sometimes they go in, sometimes they don't. I'm confident in it." 
For the time being, so are the Flyers, who feel good about not squandering the extra point like they did so times in the past. 
"You want to find ways to win the close games whether it's a shootout or overtime or a one-goal game," Gagner said. "Obviously, that's good news for us going forward."
